articles.author: Rakesh KR
articles.description:
REST (REpresentational State Transfer) is an architectural style that uses identification of resources; manipulation of resources through representations; self-descriptive messages, and hypermedia as the engine of application state, to build distributed systems that are scalable and resilient to change.
The term was introduced and defined in 2000 by Roy Fielding in his doctoral dissertation. Fielding is one of the principal authors of the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) specification versions 1.0 and 1.1.
In simple language, REST is an alternative to SOAP based web services. Where SOAP tries to model the exchange between client and server as calls to objects, REST tries to be faithful to the web domain.





  
  
  Resources




Representational state transfer, on Wikipedia,
Architectural Styles and the Design of Network-based Software Architectures, Fielding's dissertation introducing REST, and his clarification regarding the necessary usage of hyper-text in REST APIs
implementing-rest on Google Code.
implementing-rest with Spring.
How to GET a Cup of Coffee
RESTful Web Clients Enabling Reuse Through Hypermedia
RESTful Web APIs
RESTful Web Services Cookbook Solutions for Improving Scalability and Simplicity
RESTful Web Services for the real world
articles.title: In One Minute : REST (REpresentational State Transfer)

articles.author: Necati √ñzmen
articles.description:
Author: Muhammad Khabbab
Monorepos are very popular in modern application development because of their immense benefits. A monorepo is a single repository having multiple distinct projects with well-defined associations. Note that monorepo is not a monolith; in fact, it is the opposite of a monolith.  
It is very easy to make cross-cutting code changes across different applications (/backend, /frontend) in a single atomic commit. It also provides a single source of truth for various environmental concerns you would want to be applied uniformly across your organization. Some examples include dependency management, code reuse from shared packages, etc. Because of the powerful features of monorepo that tech giants like Google and Facebook have adopted monorepo. Even major Javascript tools lik‚Ä¶
articles.title: What is Turborepo and Why Should You Care?

articles.author: Dean Radcliffe
articles.description:
TL;DR The Radcliffe Concurrency Model is a way of understanding how a computer resource, or person responds to an interruption, which will help us understand multitasking in programming, and in life.

Interruptions are a fact of life. Nobody has the luxury of being able to single-task on each thing they start until its sweet completion. No‚Äî life is more like this: 
Kid: "Dad, I want a grilled cheese, please."
Dad: starts making a grilled cheese sandwich...

Kid: "Dad, can I have chicken nuggets?"
When we ask what we would do as the dad, we are considering which one of our Concurrency Strategies should we use? We'll list these out shortly. But first - notice that although everyone makes these strategy choices - nobody can quickly list what all the choices are! It's like we haven't studied t‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Radcliffe Concurrency Model

Foreword


During the development iterations of the Hertz framework, I became more and more familiar with Hertz's main library. In the next few articles, I will analyze Hertz's service registration, service discovery and load balancing expansion respectively, and finally use the etcd expansion adapted to Hertz for actual combat. Welcome everyone to pay attention.
Hertz is an ultra-large-scale enterprise-level microservice HTTP framework, featuring high ease of use, easy expansion, and low latency etc.
Hertz uses the self-developed high-performance network library Netpoll by default. In some special scenarios, Hertz has certain advantages in QPS and latency compared to go net.
In internal practice, some typical services, such as services with a high proportion of frameworks, gateways and ot‚Ä¶

articles.author: Chris Bongers
articles.description:
With Next 13 the team made quite big changes regarding how components render.
So let's take a closer look at how rendering works in Next 13.
We'll first have to address what is seen as the server and the client.
Server: A actual server that hosts your code can receive a request, do some calculations and send back a response once those are complete.
Client: The browser a user's device sends a request to the server and does some calculations in the browser to render the correct layout.
As you can see, the tipping point lies in where the calculations happen.
So what exactly did the ecosystem look like before Next 13?
In general, with React, everything happens on the client side. Next solve this by breaking your React components down into pages that could partially be rendered on the server.
W‚Ä¶
articles.title: Next 13 - Server and Client components

articles.author: Tapajyoti Bose
articles.description:
Tired of memorizing git commands? Here is a cheat sheet with 40+ commands to simplify your life.
git init <directory>

The <directory> is optional. If you don't specify it, the current directory will be used.
git clone <url>

git add <file>

To add all files in the current directory, use . in place of <file>.
git add .

git commit -m "<message>"

If you want to add all changes made to tracked files & commit
git commit -a -m "<message>"

# or

git commit -am "<message>"

git reset <file>

git mv <current path> <new path>

git rm <file>

You can also remove it from staging area only using --cached flag
git rm --cached <file>

Default branch name: main

Default remote name: origin

Current branch reference: HEAD

Parent of HEAD: HEAD^ or HEAD~1

Grandparent of HEAD: HEAD^^ or HEAD~2




  
  ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Git Cheat Sheet with 40+ commands & concepts

articles.author: ReactJS Guru
articles.description:
In this article, we are going to make a stopwatch in react. Like a basic stopwatch we will have a display to show time, then we will have basic buttons for start, stop, resume and reset. As soon we will hit the start button, timer will be started and two buttons will appear stop and reset. By clicking stop, the timer will be stopped, and a resume button will appear. Lastly, the reset button will reset the timer back to 0 again.
So basically this is going to be a beginner-friendly project, so let‚Äôs make this project step-by-step.
Basic knowledge of ReactJS.
Basic knowledge of React hooks.
Basic knowledge of React props.
Good knowledge of React Components.
Let us start with App.js component, we have imported DisplayComponent.js and BtnComponent.js components, in which we will add structure for button and display. Then we also imported useState hook, so we can make use of it to get variable time. Now we have created state for time with initial 0 values for ms,s,m,h, which is actually for millisecond, second,minute and hour.
Then in return statement, we have called these two components in a div. And we have passed time as a prop for . Okay, so this is not for all for App.js we will do some changes as we progress in the Application.

Â∞±ÂÉèÂÖ∂‰ªñ‰ªª‰Ωï‰∫ãÊÉÖ‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÔºåÂÅöÂà∞ÂÆåÁæéÊòØÈúÄË¶ÅÊó∂Èó¥ÁöÑÔºå‰ΩÜ Lua ÊòØÂæàÊòì‰∫éÂ≠¶‰π†ÔºàÂπ∂‰∏îÊúâË∂£ÔºâÁöÑËØ≠Ë®Ä„ÄÇÂÆÉÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßç‰∏ÄËá¥ÁöÑËØ≠Ë®Ä„ÄÅ‰∏ÄÁßçÂ∏¶ÊúâÊúâÁî®ÁöÑÈîôËØØÊ∂àÊÅØÁöÑÂèãÂ•ΩÁöÑËØ≠Ë®ÄÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ÁΩë‰∏äËΩªÊùæÊâæÂà∞ËÆ∏Â§öÊúâÁî®ÁöÑËµÑÊñô„ÄÇÈÇ£‰πàÂ∞±ËÆ©Êàë‰ª¨ÂºÄÂßãÂêßÔºÅ

ÂÆâË£Ö Lua

‰∏≠ÂõΩËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫Â≠¶‰ºöÔºàCCFÔºâÊòØ‰∏≠ÂõΩËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ÂèäÁõ∏ÂÖ≥È¢ÜÂüüÁöÑÊùÉÂ®ÅÊú∫ÊûÑÔºå‰∏∫‰øÉËøõËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ÁßëÂ≠¶‰∏éÊäÄÊúØÁöÑÂàõÊñ∞ÂíåËøõÊ≠•ÔºåCCF ËÆæÁ´ã‰∏≠ÂõΩËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫Â≠¶‰ºöÂ•ñÔºàCCF Â•ñÔºâÔºåÊó®Âú®ÈºìÂä±Âú®ËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ÁßëÂ≠¶„ÄÅÊäÄÊúØÊàñÂ∑•Á®ãÈ¢ÜÂüüÂÖ∑ÊúâÈáçË¶ÅÂèëÁé∞„ÄÅÂèëÊòé„ÄÅÂéüÂßãÂàõÊñ∞ÔºåÂú®Áõ∏ÂÖ≥È¢ÜÂüüÊúâ‰∏ÄÂÆöÂõΩÈôÖÂΩ±ÂìçÁöÑ‰ºòÁßÄÊàêÊûúÔºåÂõ†ÂÖ∂‰∏ì‰∏öÊÄßÂíåÂÖ¨‰ø°Âäõ,Â∑≤Êàê‰∏∫ÂõΩÂÜÖÊúÄ‰∏∫ÊùÉÂ®ÅÁöÑË°°Èáè‰ºÅ‰∏ö„ÄÅÈ´òÊ†°ÊäÄÊúØÂàõÊñ∞Ê∞¥Âπ≥ÁöÑÁßëÊäÄÂ•ñÈ°π„ÄÇ

Êï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÊòØ‚ÄúËΩØ‰ª∂‰∫ß‰∏öÁöáÂÜ†‰∏äÁöÑÊòéÁè†‚ÄùÔºåÊòØÊï∞Â≠óÂü∫Á°ÄËÆæÊñΩ‰∏çÂèØÊàñÁº∫ÁöÑÂ∫ïÂ∫ß‰πã‰∏Ä„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÈöæÂ∫¶Â§ßÔºå‰∫ß‰∏öÊäïÂÖ•Âë®ÊúüÈïøÔºåËø´ÂàáÈúÄË¶ÅÂáùËÅö‰∫ß‰∏öÂäõÈáèÂÖ±Âª∫Âü∫Á°ÄËÉΩÂäõ„ÄÇopenGauss¬†ÂÆö‰ΩçÊòØ‰ºÅ‰∏öÁ∫ßÂºÄÊ∫êÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÔºåÈù¢ÂêëÊ†∏ÂøÉ‰∏öÂä°Âú∫ÊôØÔºåÊîØÊåÅ‰ºÅ‰∏ö‰∏öÂä°Êï∞Â≠óÂåñËΩ¨Âûã„ÄÇËá™¬†2020¬†Âπ¥¬†6¬†Êúà¬†30¬†Êó•Ê≠£ÂºèÂºÄÊ∫ê‰∏äÁ∫ø‰ª•Êù•ÔºåÂú®Êï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÊ†∏ÂøÉÊäÄÊúØÊñπÈù¢ÊåÅÁª≠Á™ÅÁ†¥Ôºå‰∏é‰∫ß‰∏öÈìæ‰ºô‰º¥ÂÖ±Âª∫ÂõΩÂÖßÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÂºÄÊ∫êÊ†πÁ§æÂå∫ÔºåÂÖ±ÂêåÁπÅËç£Êï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÂºÄÊ∫êÁîüÊÄÅ„ÄÅÂπ∂Âú®Ë°å‰∏öÊ†∏ÂøÉÂú∫ÊôØ‰∏≠ËßÑÊ®°Â∫îÁî®ÔºåÊàê‰∏∫‰∏≠ÂõΩÂèëÂ±ïÊúÄÂø´ÁöÑÂºÄÊ∫êÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÁ§æÂå∫„ÄÇ

ÊäÄÊúØÊñπÈù¢ÔºåopenGauss¬†Âü∫‰∫éÂçé‰∏∫Â§öÂπ¥Âú®Êï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÈ¢ÜÂüüÁöÑÊäÄÊúØÂíåÁªèÈ™åÁßØÁ¥ØÔºå‰∏é‰ºô‰º¥ÂçèÂêåÂàõÊñ∞Ôºå‚ÄúÂõõÈ´ò‚ÄùËÉΩÂäõÊåÅÁª≠ÊºîËøõÁ™ÅÁ†¥„ÄÇÈ´òÊÄßËÉΩÔºåÂ§öÊ†∏¬†NUMA¬†ÊÑüÁü•ÂèäËûçÂêàÂ≠òÂÇ®ÂºïÊìéÁöÑÈ´òÊÄßËÉΩÊäÄÊúØÔºåÂçïËäÇÁÇπÂÆûÁé∞¬†230¬†‰∏á¬†tpmC ÊÄßËÉΩ ÔºåÂ∏ÆÂä©ÂÆ¢Êà∑Â∫îÂØπÊï∞Â≠óÂåñËΩ¨ÂûãÁöÑÊÄßËÉΩÊåëÊàò„ÄÇÈ´òÂèØÁî®ÔºåÊï∞ÊçÆÈõ∂‰∏¢Â§±„ÄÅRTO<10sÔºà‰∏öÂä°ÊÅ¢Â§çÊó∂Èó¥Â∞è‰∫é¬†10¬†ÁßíÔºâÔºåÊîØÊåÅÂü∫‰∫é¬†Paxos¬†ÁöÑÈáëËûçÁ∫ßÂ§öÂú∞Â§ö‰∏≠ÂøÉÂèØÁî®ÊÄß„ÄÇÈ´òÂÆâÂÖ®ÊñπÈù¢ÔºåÈÄöËøáÂÖ®ÂØÜÊÄÅÊäÄÊúØÔºåËÆ©Â≠òÂÇ®Âú®Êï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆ‚ÄúÂèØÁî®‰∏çÂèØËßÅÔºåÂèØËßÅ‰∏çÂèØÊîπÔºåÁØ°ÊîπÂèØËøΩÊ∫Ø‚ÄùÔºå‰øùÈöúÊï∞ÊçÆÂÖ®ÁîüÂëΩÂë®ÊúüÁöÑÂÆâÂÖ®ÂèØ‰ø°ÔºåÂΩìÂâçÂ∑≤Ëé∑ÂæóÂõΩÂÜÖÈ¶ñ‰∏™ÂÖ®ÁêÉÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÂÆâÂÖ®ÊúÄÈ´òÁ≠âÁ∫ßÁöÑ¬†CC EAL 4+¬†ËÆ§ËØÅ„ÄÇÈ´òÊô∫ËÉΩÔºåËûçÂêàÂºÇÊûÑÁ°¨‰ª∂ÁöÑÈ´òÊô∫ËÉΩÊäÄÊúØÔºåÂåÖÊã¨Á™ÅÁ†¥ÂºÇÊûÑËÆ°ÁÆóÁÆóÂ≠êÂä†ÈÄüÊäÄÊúØÔºåÁ™ÅÁ†¥Âü∫‰∫éÂºÇÊûÑÁ°¨‰ª∂Ê®°ÂûãËÆ≠ÁªÉÂä†ÈÄüÁÆóÊ≥ïÔºåÁ™ÅÁ†¥Âü∫‰∫éÂêëÈáèÂåñÂõæÁâáÊ£ÄÁ¥¢Á≠âÊäÄÊúØÔºåÊûÅÂ§ßÊèêÈ´òËøêÁª¥ÊïàÁéá„ÄÅÈáäÊîæÁîü‰∫ßÂäõ„ÄÇÊåÅÁª≠Ê∑±ËÄïÂàõÊñ∞ÔºåopenGauss¬†Â∑≤ÁªèÊàê‰∏∫‰∏≠ÂõΩÊúÄÂÖ∑ÂàõÈ´òÊñ∞ÂäõÁöÑÂºÄÊ∫êÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ì„ÄÇ

Èô§‰∫ÜÂú®ÊäÄÊúØ‰∏äÁöÑÊåÅÁª≠ÂàõÊñ∞ÔºåopenGauss¬†Á§æÂå∫‰πüÊÑàÂèëÁπÅËç£„ÄÇÊà™Ëá≥ÁõÆÂâçÔºåopenGauss¬†Â∑≤Âú®ÊäÄÊúØ„ÄÅÁîüÊÄÅ„ÄÅÂïÜ‰∏öÂíåÁ§æÂå∫Ê≤ªÁêÜÁ≠âÁ®≥ÂÅ•Êé®ËøõÔºåÂø´ÈÄüÊàêÈïøÔºå185¬†ÂÆ∂‰ºÅ‰∏öÂíåÊú∫ÊûÑÂä†ÂÖ•Á§æÂå∫Ôºå4000¬†Â§öÂêçÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÂèÇ‰∏éÁ§æÂå∫Ë¥°ÁåÆÔºåÁ§æÂå∫ÁâàÊú¨‰∏ãËΩΩÈáèË∂Ö¬†100¬†‰∏áÊ¨°„ÄÇÂêåÊó∂ÔºåÊê∫Êâã‰∫ß‰∏öÈìæ‰ºô‰º¥ËÅöÁÑ¶Ë°å‰∏öÂÆ¢Êà∑Â∫îÁî®Âú∫ÊôØÈúÄÊ±ÇÔºå‰∏∫ÂÆ¢Êà∑Êèê‰æõÈ¢ÜÂÖàÁöÑ‰∫ßÂìÅ‰∏éÊñπÊ°à„ÄÇÁõÆÂâç¬†openGauss¬†‰∏éÊµ∑ÈáèÊï∞ÊçÆ„ÄÅ‰∫ëÂíåÊÅ©Â¢®„ÄÅÁ•ûËàüÈÄöÁî®„ÄÅÂçóÂ§ßÈÄöÁî®Á≠â¬†10¬†‰ΩôÂÆ∂‰ºô‰º¥Âêà‰ΩúÂèëË°åÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÂïÜ‰∏öÁâàÔºå‰∏é¬†ISV¬†‰ºô‰º¥ËÅîÂêàÊûÑÁ≠ëÂü∫‰∫é¬†openGauss¬†ÁöÑË°å‰∏öËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°à¬†500¬†‰Ωô‰∏™ÔºåÂπ∂Âú®ÂõΩËÆ°Ê∞ëÁîüË°å‰∏öÂÆûÁé∞ËßÑÊ®°ÂïÜÁî®ÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠Â∑≤Âú®‰∏≠ÂõΩÁßªÂä®„ÄÅÈÇÆÂÇ®Èì∂Ë°å„ÄÅ‰∏≠ÂõΩÊµ∑Ê≤π„ÄÅ‰∏≠ÂõΩ‰∫∫ÂØø„ÄÅÂõΩÂÆ∂ÁîµÁΩë„ÄÅÊ∞ëÁîüÈì∂Ë°å„ÄÅÊØî‰∫öËø™Á≠âÂÆ¢Êà∑ÁöÑÊ†∏ÂøÉÁ≥ªÁªüÊâπÈáè‰∏äÁ∫ø„ÄÇ

openGauss¬†ÂùöÊåÅÂàõÊñ∞ÔºåËÅöÁÑ¶Êï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÊ†πÊäÄÊúØÂèëÂ±ïÔºå‰ΩøËÉΩ‰ºÅ‰∏öÊï∞Â≠óÂåñËΩ¨Âûã„ÄÇopenGauss¬†ÂùöÊåÅÂºÄÊ∫êÂºÄÊîæÔºå‰∏é‰∫ß‰∏öÈìæÂàõÊñ∞ÂäõÈáè‰∏ÄËµ∑ÔºåÂÖ±Âª∫„ÄÅÂÖ±‰∫´„ÄÅÂÖ±Ê≤ªÔºåÂçèÂäõÊâìÈÄ†ÂÖ®ÁêÉÈ¢ÜÂÖàÁöÑÂºÄÊ∫êÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìÂºÄÊ∫êÁ§æÂå∫ÂíåÊäÄÊúØÁîüÊÄÅ„ÄÇ

Ë¢´Ë™â‰∏∫‚ÄúÂÖ®ÁêÉÁßëÊäÄÊàêÊûúÂèëÂ±ïÈ£éÂêëÊ†á‚ÄùÁöÑÂπ¥Â∫¶È¢ÜÂÖàÁßëÊäÄÊàêÊûúÂ§ßÂ•ñ‰∫é‰∏ñÁïå‰∫íËÅîÁΩëÂ§ß‰ºöÈ¶ñÊó•Êè≠Êôì„ÄÇopenEuler¬†ÂºÄÊ∫êÊìç‰ΩúÁ≥ªÁªüÂá≠ÂÄüÂú®ÂºÄÊ∫êÊìç‰ΩúÁ≥ªÁªüÈ¢ÜÂüüÁöÑÂàõÊñ∞ÊàêÊûúËé∑ÂæóÂ§ß‰ºöËØÑÂßî‰ºö‰∏ÄËá¥ËÆ§ÂèØÔºåÂπ∂ÊúÄÁªàÊëòÂæó‚ÄúÂÖ®ÁêÉÈ¢ÜÂÖàÁßëÊäÄÊàêÊûúÂ§ßÂ•ñ‚Äù„ÄÇÊ≠§Ê¨°Ëé∑Â•ñÔºåÊòØ¬†openEuler¬†Á§æÂå∫ÊàêÂçÉ‰∏ä‰∏á‰ºô‰º¥ÂíåÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÂÖ±ÂêåË¥°ÁåÆÁöÑÊàêÊûú„ÄÇ



‰∏ñÁïå‰∫íËÅîÁΩëÈ¢ÜÂÖàÁßëÊäÄÊàêÊûúÂ§ßÂ•ñÂ±ïÁé∞‰∫ÜÂÖ®ÁêÉ¬†ICT¬†È¢ÜÂüüÊúÄÊñ∞ÊäÄÊúØÔºåÂπ∂ËÅöÁÑ¶ÂàõÊñ∞ÊäÄÊúØÂú®ÁßëÊäÄÊäóÁñ´„ÄÅÂ§çÂ∑•Â§ç‰∫ß„ÄÅÊé®Âä®Êï∞Â≠óÁªèÊµéÂèëÂ±ï‰∏éÂêà‰ΩúÁ≠âÈ¢ÜÂüüÁöÑÊúÄ‰Ω≥ÂÆûË∑µ„ÄÇÊ≠§Ê¨°ÂèëÂ∏ÉÂÖ±ËØÑÈÄâÂá∫¬†15¬†È°πÂ§ßÂ•ñÔºåÊ∂âÂèä‰∫∫Â∑•Êô∫ËÉΩ„ÄÅ5G„ÄÅÂ§ßÊï∞ÊçÆ„ÄÅ‰∫ëËÆ°ÁÆó„ÄÅÊï∞Â≠óÂåñÂà∂ÈÄ†„ÄÅÂ∑•‰∏ö‰∫íËÅîÁ≠âÂ§ö‰∏™ÊñπÈù¢„ÄÇÂÖ±¬†34¬†Âêç‰∫íËÅîÁΩëÈ¢ÜÂüüÁöÑ‰∏≠Â§ñÁü•Âêç‰∏ìÂÆ∂ÁªÑÊàê‚Äú‰∏ñÁïå‰∫íËÅîÁΩëÈ¢ÜÂÖàÁßëÊäÄÊàêÊûú‰∏ìÂÆ∂Êé®ËçêÂßîÂëò‰ºö‚ÄùÔºåÁî±ÂÖ®ÂõΩÊîøÂçèÂâØ‰∏ªÂ∏≠„ÄÅËá¥ÂÖ¨ÂÖö‰∏≠Â§Æ‰∏ªÂ∏≠„ÄÅ‰∏≠ÂõΩÁßëÂçè‰∏ªÂ∏≠‰∏áÈí¢ÊãÖ‰ªªÂêçË™â‰∏ª‰ªªÔºåÁî±ÂÖ®ÂõΩÊîøÂçèÂâØ‰∏ªÂ∏≠„ÄÅ‰∏≠ÂõΩÂ∑•Á®ãÈô¢Èô¢Â£´ÈÇ¨Ë¥∫Èì®ÊãÖ‰ªª‰∏≠Êñπ‰∏ª‰ªªÔºåÊåâÁÖß‚ÄúÂÖ¨Âπ≥„ÄÅÂÖ¨Ê≠£„ÄÅÂÆ¢ËßÇ„ÄÅÊùÉÂ®Å‚ÄùÂéüÂàôÔºåÁªè‰∏ìÂÆ∂Êé®ËçêÂßîÂëò‰ºöÊúÄÁªàÊé®Ëçê„ÄÇ

openEuler¬†Á§æÂå∫ÁêÜ‰∫ãÈïøÊ±üÂ§ßÂãáÂêë‰∏é‰ºöÂòâÂÆæ‰ªãÁªç‰∫Ü¬†openEulerÔºå‰ªñË°®Á§∫ÔºåopenEuler¬†ÊòØÂÖ®ÁêÉÈ¶ñ‰∏™Èù¢ÂêëÊï∞Â≠óÂü∫Á°ÄËÆæÊñΩÁöÑÂÖ®Âú∫ÊôØÂºÄÊ∫êÊìç‰ΩúÁ≥ªÁªüÔºåÂπ∂Á™ÅÁ†¥ÊÄßÁöÑÂÆûÁé∞‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÂ•ó¬†OS¬†Êû∂ÊûÑ‰∏ãÔºåÊîØÊåÅÂ§öÊ†∑ÊÄßËÆæÂ§áÔºõ‰∏ªÊµÅËÆ°ÁÆóÊû∂ÊûÑ¬†100%¬†Ë¶ÜÁõñÔºåÊàê‰∏∫ÊúÄ‰Ω≥ÊîØÊåÅÂ§öÊ†∑ÊÄßÁÆóÂäõÁöÑÂºÄÊ∫êÊìç‰ΩúÁ≥ªÁªü„ÄÇÂêåÊó∂ÔºåÊ¨ßÊãâÂºÄÂàõÊÄßÁöÑÊèêÂá∫‰∫ÜÂÖ®Ê†àÂéüÂ≠êÂåñËß£ËÄ¶ÔºåÊîØÊåÅÁâàÊú¨ÁÅµÊ¥ªÊûÑÂª∫„ÄÅÊúçÂä°Ëá™Áî±ÁªÑÂêà„ÄÇÈÄöËøá‰∏ÄÂ•óÊìç‰ΩúÁ≥ªÁªüÊû∂ÊûÑÔºåÂÆûÁé∞‰∫ÜÂØπÊúçÂä°Âô®„ÄÅ‰∫ëËÆ°ÁÆó„ÄÅËæπÁºòËÆ°ÁÆóÂíåÂµåÂÖ•ÂºèÁ≠âÂú∫ÊôØÁöÑÊîØÊåÅ„ÄÇÂêåÊó∂ÔºåÊ¨ßÊãâÁ§æÂå∫ÁßâÊâø‚ÄúÂÖ±Âª∫„ÄÅÂÖ±‰∫´„ÄÅÂÖ±Ê≤ª‚ÄùÁöÑÁêÜÂøµÔºåÊé¢Á¥¢ÂºÄÊ∫êÊñ∞Ê®°ÂºèÔºå‰∏∫‰∏≠ÂõΩÂºÄÊ∫ê‰ΩìÁ≥ªÂª∫ËÆæÂÅöÂá∫Ë¥°ÁåÆ„ÄÇÊ¨ßÊãâÁ´ãË∂≥‰∏≠ÂõΩ„ÄÅËûçÂÖ•ÂÖ®ÁêÉÔºåÊâìÈÄ†ÁπÅËç£ÁöÑÂü∫Á°ÄËΩØ‰ª∂Êñ∞ÁîüÊÄÅ„ÄÇ

articles.author: Seth Kenlon
articles.description:
Use a hashmap in Java
Seth Kenlon
Sun, 11/13/2022 - 03:00

            
In the Java programming language, a hashmap is a list of associated values. Java uses hashmaps to store data. If you keep a lot of structured data, it's useful to know the various retrieval methods available.

More on Java
What is enterprise Java programming?
An open source alternative to Oracle JDK
Java cheat sheet
Red Hat build of OpenJDK
Free online course: Developing cloud-native applications with microservices
Fresh Java articles
Create a hashmap
Create a hashmap in Java by importing and using the HashMap class. When you create a hashmap, you must define what constitutes a valid value (such as Integer or String). A hashmap holds pairs of values.
package com.opensource.example;
import java.util.HashMap;
public clas‚Ä¶
articles.title: Use a hashmap in Java

articles.author: Don Watkins
articles.description:
Learn Python: 7 of my favorite resources
Don Watkins
Sat, 11/12/2022 - 03:00

            
I made a decision recently that I wanted to learn more Python so I could improve my instructional skills and broaden the horizons of my students. In the process, I have discovered these excellent resources that have me learning new code and improving my understanding of Python in general.
1. Teach your kids to code
I began the Python journey about seven years ago when I discovered connections between Apple LOGO and the Turtle module in Python. The Linux computer I was using at the time defaulted to Python 2.7, and I soon discovered that I wanted to use Python 3. I managed to get it installed and began writing some simple programs using the Turtle module. After reading Dr.¬†Bryson Payne‚Äôs Teach Your Ki‚Ä¶

articles.author: Jessica Cherry
articles.description:
How to switch from Twitter to Mastodon
Jessica Cherry
Fri, 11/11/2022 - 03:00

            
Like many people, I find social media somewhat exciting and also...a bit much. Sometimes you get deep-fried in algorithms, tracking data, and ads catered especially for you. You lack administrative control over what you want to see, especially on the old platforms many of us are used to. As usual, you must look to open source to fix the problem. And that's exactly what Mastodon, an open source microblogging community, does.
With Mastodon social, not only are you working with open source software, but everything is decentralized, which means you can pick what you want to see partly based on the instance you want to occupy. Mastodon uses separate instances, each with its own code of conduct, privacy o‚Ä¶
articles.title: How to switch from Twitter to Mastodon

articles.author: David Both
articles.description:
Drop swap for zram on Linux
David Both
Fri, 11/11/2022 - 03:00

            
I spend a lot of time playing (I mean working) on my computers, and I've found a lot of interesting things. One that has most recently come to my attention is the zram0 device. I first noticed it when working on one of my Opensource.com articles several months ago. It showed up in the output from the lsblk command:
# lsblk
8:0 ¬† ¬†0 931.5G ¬†0 disk
8:1 ¬† ¬†0 ¬† 600M ¬†0 part
[...]
252:0 ¬† ¬†0 ¬† ¬† 8G ¬†0 disk [SWAP]

It's identified as swap space, which is what first piqued my curiosity, so I did some exploration. Zram was originally called "compcache," which stands for "compressed cache." It turns out that zram is a tool for creating an in-RAM compressed cache, specifically for use as swap space.
But Why?

More Linux res‚Ä¶
articles.title: Drop swap for zram on Linux

articles.author: Don Watkins
articles.description:
4 key differences between Twitter and Mastodon
Don Watkins
Thu, 11/10/2022 - 03:00

            
Social media is not always sociable, and sometimes we need a sufficient impetus to change what we do and what we read. I began using Twitter as a replacement for my RSS reader in 2008, which revolutionized how I read and learned up to that point. Tweets from educators and free and open source (FOSS) advocates worldwide kept me informed and engaged in a learning network that was without equal. That's changed over the past half dozen years, and recently a change in ownership and the shaping of what I read was driven more by an algorithm than by my personal interests and choices. During a yearly meetup of correspondents and editors of Opensource.com a few years ago, Seth Kenlon suggested giving Ma‚Ä¶
articles.title: 4 key differences between Twitter and Mastodon

articles.author: Yacine Si Tayeb, PhD
articles.description:
Audit your sharding database algorithm
Yacine Si Tayeb, PhD
Thu, 11/10/2022 - 03:00

            
Thanks to the ShardingSphere community's continuous review and feedback to develop features such as data sharding and read/write splitting, our team found that some users create many shards when using the data sharding feature.
In such cases, there can be 1,000 physical tables corresponding to a sharding logical table, which disturbs users.
For instance, a SELECT * FROM t_order statement will lead to a full-route, which is obviously not the case for OLTP. This SQL can be placed in another Proxy to avoid blocking other requests.
However, if users are not familiar with Proxy or how to write a where condition and don't know that sharding is not supported in this condition, a full-route is still r‚Ä¶
articles.title: Audit your sharding database algorithm

articles.author: Seth Kenlon
articles.description:
Why sysadmins should choose Awesome window manager on Linux
Seth Kenlon
Wed, 11/09/2022 - 03:00

            
Awesome is a window manager for the Linux desktop. A "window manager" is a graphical interface that primarily (if not literally) just manages the drawing and arrangement of windows. In practice, even the most rudimentary of window managers actually provides a little more than just the ability to draw a window. Most also provide a pop-up menu so you can launch an application, some provide a dock or panel so you can switch between different applications you have running. They stop short at providing desktop conveniences such as drawing a wallpaper in the background of your screen, mounting and unmounting devices, providing a system tray, and so on. A window manager assumes you can us‚Ä¶
articles.title: Why sysadmins should choose Awesome window manager on Linux

articles.description:
Using Python in VS Code and Codium
Don Watkins
Wed, 11/09/2022 - 03:00

            
Over the past couple of years, I have had the privilege of working with middle school children to introduce them to Python coding and the Raspberry Pi 400. It's been a lot of fun, and the Pi has been a great platform for the students and me. We've used Code with Mu and it's been quite successful. Our aptitude with Python has grown with experience, and so recently I started looking for ways to offer these students more.
I participated in a Python learning class, and during that class I got introduced to Microsoft's Visual Studio Code. I learned a lot in that class about how to set up a virtual environment for Python, and how to configure VS Code for Python programming. During that learning journey, I also g‚Ä¶
articles.title: Using Python in VS Code and Codium

What stickers are on your laptop?

Having just switched work laptops last December, I realized how much I love applying stickers to my work machines. Sometimes the stickers are souvenirs from past events, others are from projects that I am passionate about, and some are just for fun!

articles.author: Katie Edwards
articles.description:
What you actually need to know about open source to get started
Katie Edwards
Mon, 11/07/2022 - 03:00

            
So you want (or need) to figure out what "open source" really means. I'll cover the basics of open source, whether you're interested in contributing to a project or want to be in the loop at a new job where the term keeps getting thrown around.
Full disclosure: I am a person with little technical experience, working in the content-design fringes of a very technical open source environment. Given my background in marketing and communication, I felt like a fish out of water when I made this career switch. Git, data science, the ins and outs of software‚Ä¶ It was, and still is a year later, a lot to comprehend.
But that's why I'm writing this piece. I want to help make open source‚Ä¶
articles.title: What you actually need to know about open source to get started

Republicans predicted a ‚Äúred wave‚Äù that would crush any hopes of a Democratic majority this election cycle. But as the dust settles and vote counts wrap up, that prediction has shattered. 
While Republicans saw success in states like Florida and New York, Democrats fared better in battleground states, where polls often significantly underestimated their support. On the eve of the election, FiveThirtyEight‚Äôs poll average had Dr. Mehmet Oz ahead by just half a point, only to see him lose by 4 percent in the final tally. In Michigan, the same average put incumbent Governor Gretchen Whitmer only five points ahead of her Republican challenger; but on election day, she won by more than 10 points.
Many Democratic strategists and White House...

articles.title: Why can‚Äôt pollsters reach Gen Z?

articles.description:
@SocialBoat

Today we launch SocialBoat for Women. Motivation to create this came from my mom's (@seema_jain3) fitness journey. I have seen the handwork and struggles she put in to get fit and how it essentially transformed her life. 

Some critical problems that I saw -
1. Lack of time 
My mom used to manage the home, and this essentially made her mornings and evenings very busy. Mid day is usually too hot to workout outside and fitness centers are usually closed at this time.

I would see her get up at 5am :sunny: everyday, to go for her quick 30 minute walk.

2. Lack of relevant programs 
My mom gained a lot of weight post her pregnancy, and she struggled to find any relevant programs to lose it. Most gyms had male oriented bulk up programs, and fitness classes were usually too intensive for her.

She started learning Yoga from a book, and then Pilates from YouTube videos. She tells me it took her 4 years to gain the confidence she had back in college.

3. Her New Program for women 
After her at home transformation, she learnt jazz and hip hop dance, performed at multiple venues around the country and recently started a fitness program for women called - Yogalates. An amalgamation of yoga, pilates and dance for women.

She takes classes on zoom and more than 100 women have joined her program.

Scaling up the concept 
Our goal with SocialBoat is to take some of these learnings and make high quality fitness accessible to >100M women around the country.

- A program one can follow from their home
- Is accessible anytime during the day
- Tailored to women specific needs
- Evolves with different life stages

Excited to see how people at ProductHunt find it. Please reach out to us if you have any questions or suggestions!

Thank you
              ‚Äù

articles.description:
@tw__ recently got into programming and so we decided to build a small project together. It was important to us that it had a manageable scope but was still useful. So we agreed to build a wishlist app that let's you organize your wishes and share them with your friends and family.

There are already dozens of apps like this out there with similar features, but we found them incredibly frustrating and confusing to use, therefore our goal was to try and build an app that works better and has a more modern look.

Some highlights of the Wishbear üêª app:

- üë§ No registration required, starting to use the app is literally just a single click of a button. Your session will be stored in your browser but you can submit your email address at any time in order to access your wishlists on other devices.

- ‚ú® When you add a wish from a link to an online shop, the product details will be loaded for you automatically. That works for almost every shop out there, with a few exceptions that don't provide metadata or block our crawler.

- üîê Visitors of your wishlist can mark your wishes as reserved so that nothing is given away twice.

Give it a try, it's really easy to get started and we'd love to hear what you think!

Cheers,
Niklas & Thomas
              ‚Äù
